tweet: Interesting attack on Monero traceability. Essentially, the attacker floods the network with his own transactions, and is able to remove them from the mixins later to identify other inputs. Costs only $1.5k for a year long attack.

Pretty 🔥 paper on Monero traceability.  Researchers propose an attack that takes advantage of Bulletproofs and floods the network with cheap transactions which remove mixins from tx inputs.  - $1,746 for a 12-months attack 😱 - up to 47.63% inputs traced   https://t.co/2XAU66wqSg  https://t.co/iBPkUho10d

FinCEN’s new cryptocurrency guidance matches Coin Center recommendations; Multi-sig wallets, decentralized exchanges, and privacy protecting cryptocurrency developers are not regulated - by Coin Center   https://t.co/Va2CXIPMsu

UPDATE: Researchers might have falsely assumed that a Monero transaction can have up to 100 outputs. The actual limit seem to be 16.  Unfortunately, this doesn't change the severity of the attack since it would only make it 6x more expensive (~$10,500 for a 12-months attack).
@el33th4xor Multiple incorrect assumptions in that paper. The authors simulations aren't anywhere close to how the Monero network actually operates. Atrociously sloppy work.  https://t.co/81u1qaQVNi

@el33th4xor Already discussed in the linked reddit discussion. Author assumes 100-output txns with 4 mixins, Monero network limits to 16 outputs, requires 10 mixins. Assumes tx fees increase logarithmically, but fee algorithm was changed when BPs were deployed.
